entry.title: Armenia now most democratic country in region, says Freedom House

media:group.media:title: Armenia now most democratic country in region, says Freedom House
media:group.media:description:
üìçNagorno-Karabakh President Arayik Harutyunyan slammed Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan for saying he is ready to recognize Azerbaijan‚Äôs claims to the region. üìçIn this year‚Äôs Nations in Transit report, Freedom House drew parallels between Russia‚Äôs occupation of Ukraine and Azerbaijan‚Äôs aggression against Armenia and Nagorno-Karabakh. üìçRepresentatives of China Southern Airlines have met with the leadership of Armenia International Airports to discuss launching direct flights between China and Armenia.
#CivilNet #’ç’´’æ’´’¨’Ü’•’© #dailyarmenia

entry.title: TURKEY VOTES: ‚ÄòAliyev is becoming a tool against Turkish democracy‚Äô

media:group.media:title: TURKEY VOTES: ‚ÄòAliyev is becoming a tool against Turkish democracy‚Äô
media:group.media:description:
As Turkey heads to the polls on Sunday for a second round of presidential elections, former candidate Sinan Oƒüan announced over the weekend that he is endorsing incumbent President Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan. Aras Editor-in-Chief Rober Kopta≈ü joins CivilNet to discuss Oƒüan‚Äôs connections with Azerbaijan and how Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev has influenced the general elections.
Also watch:

entry.title: Pashinyan‚Äôs solution will not bring peace, says former Armenian minister

media:group.media:title: Pashinyan‚Äôs solution will not bring peace, says former Armenian minister
media:group.media:description:
Artsakh‚Äôs parliament convened an extraordinary session today regarding Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan‚Äôs remarks Monday, where the latter said he would accept Karabakh as part of Azerbaijan. Former Karabakh Presidents Arkady Ghukasyan and Bako Sahakyan, former Armenian Presidents Levon Ter-Petrossian, Robert Kocharyan and Serzh Sargsyan, as well as former Armenian Foreign Minister Vardan Osaknyan all released statements slamming Pashinyan‚Äôs remarks, and describing it is a gross violation of the Armenian Constitution.
#CivilNet #’ç’´’æ’´’¨’Ü’•’©

entry.title: 2023 to be record-breaking year for tourism in Armenia

media:group.media:title: 2023 to be record-breaking year for tourism in Armenia
media:group.media:description:
Sisian Boghossian, head of Armenia‚Äôs Tourism Committee, sits down with CivilNet to discuss the country‚Äôs latest tourism figures. Boghossian also talks about strategies to increase tourism, including a new direct flight to Saudi Arabia and a domestic tourism expo set to take place in Yerevan later this month.

entry.title: ‚ÄúWe have fallen, but we will rise. We cannot break‚Äù, Hon. Gassia Apkarian

media:group.media:title: ‚ÄúWe have fallen, but we will rise. We cannot break‚Äù, Hon. Gassia Apkarian
media:group.media:description:
Hon. Gassia Apkarian sits down with Lara Tcholakian to share her role and achievements as Judge of the Superior Court of Orange County in California, and the achievements that the Center for Truth and Justice (CFTJ) has made since the Artsakh war of 2020 in collecting evidence to be admissible in court.
Recently the CFTJ held its second international conference in Yerevan where various topics were raised including what it would mean for Armenia to become a member of the International Constitutional Court. Apkarian shares her story of how she was raised and educated in Lebanon, Syria and the US, and the values and qualities she acquired from her uprooted lifestyle in the diaspora. She also expresses her thoughts about the future of Armenia, as well as the importance of having hope and finding purpose in life. Finally, she shares the continuous battle and challenges she faces as a woman leader.
About Hon. Gassia Apkarian is a judge at the Superior Court of Orange County in California, a position she holds since 2014. Prior to that, she was a Senior Attorney and Deputy Public Defender in Orange County. After Armenia‚Äôs earthquake in 1988, Apkarian moved to Armenia to volunteer with Land & Culture. She has been working as a volunteer in Armenia and has been returning to since then. She was Country Director for Armenia with the Armenia Assembly of America, Executive Director of ‚ÄúDemocrats 2000‚Äù in Washington D.C. as well as Campaign Manager for Robert Kocharyan during the presidential elections in 1998, followed by Advisor to the President. She received a B.A. from the University of California ‚Äì Irvine, and a J.D. from the University of La Verne College of Law.
Program overview In a new open setting, Lara deconstructs inherited cultural and historical narratives, memories, life lessons and experiences from change catalysts. Her guests reflect on the stories, people, events and mindsets that have shaped their professional and personal lives, enabling them to create a more mindful life.
#CivilNet #MindfulLeaders #InheritedLegacies

entry.title: TURKEY VOTES: Armenian ancestry weaponized in Turkish political smear campaigns

media:group.media:title: TURKEY VOTES: Armenian ancestry weaponized in Turkish political smear campaigns
media:group.media:description:
As Turkey‚Äôs presidential election heads to a runoff, slated for Sunday, Aras Publishing House Editor-in-Chief Rober Kopta≈ü joins CivilNet to discuss whether the elections are truly free and fair and explore President Erdoƒüan‚Äôs party‚Äôs tactics to influence the results. Kopta≈ü also explains that misinformation and disinformation campaigns have been used to smear candidates. One such tactic is alleging that opponents have Armenian ancestry.
Also watch: TURKEY VOTES: Erdoƒüan, Turkish opposition and Armenia normalization https://youtu.be/9iYK6qNDLQ4
TURKEY VOTES: Erdoƒüan Faces Strongest Opposition in Years https://youtu.be/6BflOIUZu9o
